document.docTitle: Penares mollis Sim-Smith & Kelly 2019, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: Review of the sponge genus Penares (Demospongiae, Tetractinellida, Astrophorina) in the New Zealand EEZ, with descriptions of new species

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Review of the sponge genus Penares (Demospongiae, Tetractinellida, Astrophorina) in the New Zealand EEZ, with descriptions of new species

.

(0CDN6636-W)
,
Three Kings Islands , 34.166° S , 172.150° E ,
16– 17 m

;

Northland :
NIWA 62309 , 34.418° S , 172.845° E ,
18 m

Type locality. Three Kings Islands, New Zealand .
Distribution. Three Kings Islands and Northland , New Zealand ( Figure 9 ). Found growing on rocky substrate in shallow waters ( 6–28 m ).

Description. Morphology is irregularly lobed ( Figure 7 A–C). The holotype is 70 mm × 60 mm × 50 mm high. Surface is very smooth, felty to the touch. Interior is fuzzy. Large uniporal oscules, 2–6 mm in diameter, and smaller uniporal pores, 0.5–0.7 mm in diameter, are sparsely scattered over the sponge, more commonly present on the apex of the lobes ( Figure 7C & D ). Texture is soft, compressible. Colour in life is grey or black, interior is cream. Colour in ethanol is grey brown, interior is beige.
Etymology. Named after the soft, compressible texture of the sponge ( mollis , soft; Latin).

Remarks. Penares mollis sp. nov. is very similar to P. tylotaster in spicule complement, the most obvious difference being that P. mollis sp. nov. has slender orthotriaenes while P. tylotaster predominantly has stouter di- chotriaenes. Penares tylotaster does have some plagiotriaenes and triaenes with a mixture of single and bifurcate clads, but dichotriaenes are much more common. The oxeas of P. mollis sp. nov. are also considerably smaller (837 (573–1282) µm) than those of P. tylotaster (1212 (978–1404) µm). All other spicule types and sizes are very similar between the two species. The two species also differ in texture— P. tylotaster is firm and rigid, whereas P. mollis sp. nov. is soft and compressible. Apart from P. mollis sp. nov. and P. tylotaster , no other New Zealand Penares species possesses tylasters.

caption.paragraph: FIGURE 7. Penares mollis sp. nov. : A. Holotype NIWA 101525 in situ ; B. Paratype NIWA 101575 fresh specimen; C. Para- type NIWA 62287 preserved in ethanol; D. Oscules and pores of NIWA 101575; E. Section showing the crust of microxeas and microrhabds in the cortex and the position of the orthotriaenes directly below the cortex; F. Close view of a choanosome section showing the abundant tylasters.

FIGURE 8.
Penares mollis
sp. nov.
, paratype NIWA 101575: A. Oxea; B. Orthotriaene; C. Tylasters; D. Microxeas; E. Microrhabd.

TABLE 3. Spicule dimensions (µm) of
Penares mollis
sp. nov.
Dimensions are given as the mean (minimum–maximum) length × mean (minimum–maximum) width (number of spicules measured). OX = oxea; OR= orthotriaene rhabdome, OC = orthotriaene clad; OCC = orthotriaene cladome; MOX = microxea; MR = microrhabd; TYL = tylaster.

subSubSection.paragraph:
There are only three other species of
Penares
described from the South Pacific:
P. micraster Lévi, 1993
and
P. palmatoclada Lévi, 1993
from New Caledonia , and
P. ochracea ( Carter, 1886 )
from Australia . The presence of tylasters in
P. mollis
sp. nov.
differentiates it from all three South Pacific species.
Penares palmatoclada
and
P. ochracea
lack euasters, while
P. micraster
possesses spherasters.
